summary: This is a declaration from a victim (Jane Doe #1 or #2) filed in a civil case against the United States regarding the non-prosecution agreement for Jeffrey Epstein. The declarant details being sexually trafficked by Epstein from approximately age 15-16, describes travel to his properties, and alleges Epstein trafficked her to other powerful men for potential blackmail. The document includes a victim notification letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office dated September 3, 2008.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually abusing and trafficking the declarant and other underage girls. Described as a billionaire who used 'massage' as a code for sexual encounters.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Named as one of the declarant's attorneys, representing her pro bono in the case to pursue criminal charges against powerful people.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.context: Named as one of the declarant's attorneys, representing her pro bono in the case to pursue criminal charges against powerful people.

persons.name: Robert Josefsberg
persons.context: Attorney selected by an independent Special Master to represent Epstein's victims in civil actions, as described in the attached victim notification letter.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Identified as Jeffrey Epstein's attorney in the victim notification letter, whom victims' counsel should contact regarding claims.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the victim notification letter dated September 3, 2008.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafa√±a
persons.context: Listed as copied on the victim notification letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Twiler Smith
persons.context: Identified in the victim notification letter as a contact for the victim to provide contact information.

connections.description: Epstein sexually abused and trafficked the declarant, starting when she was approximately 15 or 16 years old. He transported her, trained her, and controlled her through fear.
Both are listed as attorneys representing the declarant pro bono in the legal case.
Josefsberg was selected to represent victims in civil actions against Epstein, with Epstein obligated to pay his fees under certain conditions.
Goldberger is identified as Epstein's attorney in the victim notification letter.
The declarant alleges Epstein trafficked her to other powerful men for sex and required her to describe the events so he could potentially blackmail them.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Reached
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reached a non-prosecution agreement with the federal government.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to two Florida state crimes: felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution.

events.title: FBI Victim Notification
events.description: The FBI sent a victim notification letter to the declarant, informing her of Epstein's plea, the deferred federal prosecution, and the process for civil compensation.

events.title: FBI Interview in Australia
events.description: Two FBI agents met with the declarant at the U.S. Consulate in Sydney, Australia, where she provided information about Epstein and others involved in illegal acts.

events.title: Execution of Declaration
events.description: The declarant executed this sworn declaration detailing her experiences of being trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: New York City, New York (Epstein's mansion)
West Palm Beach, FL (U.S. Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: The declarant states she was approximately 15 or 16 years old when Jeffrey Epstein began sexually abusing her and trafficking her.
Epstein used 'massage' as a code word for sexual encounters with underage girls, which were a daily occurrence at his residences.

The declarant alleges Epstein trafficked her to other powerful men, including politicians and business executives, and required her to describe the sexual events so he could potentially blackmail them.
The declarant expresses fear of Epstein, stating he claimed to know powerful people and could 'get away' with things, leading her to believe he could have her killed or abducted.

A victim notification letter from September 3, 2008, reveals the U.S. government deferred federal prosecution of Epstein in light of his state guilty plea and established a process for victim compensation.
